description.plain:
Sonic Youth were a New York-based experimental rock outfit founded in 1981. Initially composed of only Kim Gordon, Thurston Moore and a revolving-door lineup of drummers, the band added Lee Ranaldo after watching him perform with experimental guitar composer Glenn Branca at the influential New York no-wave festival, Noise Fest. After a couple years and several false starts, the band finally settled on Steve Shelley (formerly of The Crucifucks) as their drummer.

From roots in no-wave and noise, Sonic Youth crafted a dissonant and thunderous sound composed of sophisticated scale systems and offbeat guitar tunings. The period between 1985’s Bad Moon Rising and 1988’s Daydream Nation is often thought of as their creative pinnacle, with the latter album acting as their seminal masterpiece.

In 1990, Sonic Youth ruffled the feathers of the nascent indie rock community by signing with major label subsidiary Geffen Records. This move ushered in a second period of relevance for the band, highlighted by heightened exposure and brief flirtations with fame. Albums like Goo, Dirty and Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star entered with Billboard Hot 100. Despite a more radio-friendly bent, the music from this period is also critically adored, with songs like “The Diamond Sea” and “100%” frequently making “Best Of” lists from the period.

The turn of the century saw a mild downturn for the band, culminating with the almost entirely noise-driven NYC Ghosts and Flowers. The release failed commercially and was panned critically, with Pitchfork famously awarding it a zero out of ten. The band made a brief return to form with albums like Rather Ripped and Sonic Nurse, which received positive reviews but never reached the commercial or iconic heights of their earlier work.

In 2011 Kim Gordon and Thurston Moore split after 27 years of marriage, effectively ending the output of Sonic Youth. While the band has never formally broken up, several members have stated in interviews that the band is finished.

songs.full_title: Teen Age Riot by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Teen Age Riot

description.plain:
The opening track of Sonic Youth’s 1988 opus Daydream Nation, “Teen Age Riot” is a sort of call for the underground audiences of New York to unite, according to Pitchfork.

The song imagines what would happen in an alternate reality if J. Mascis of Dinosaur Jr. were President of the United States, alluded to by his famous use of Marshall stacks and platform shoes.

Given these factors, it would seem the overall message the song is trying to convey is that it’s time for the various underground scenes of New York to come together and make themselves known to the mainstream. Sonic Youth, beyond the shadow of a doubt accomplished this, as they would go on to have the most recognizable careers of the 90’s.



An edited version of the track was released as a limited promo single for radios:

songs.full_title: Kool Thing by Sonic Youth (Ft. Chuck D)
songs.title: Kool Thing

description.plain:
This song was inspired by a 1989 interview Kim Gordon conducted with LL Cool J for Spin Magazine, in which the two struggled to find much in common. During the bridge, Chuck D plays the part of LL Cool J, with Gordon satirizing her own attempts to connect with him about the counterculture she identifies with.

See this article for a good summary. The full interview can be found here.

songs.title: Schizophrenia

description.plain:
Kim Gordon’s older brother, Keller, who she “grew up in awe of,” was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia and eventually came to live under supervised care.

Moore has said that “Schizophrenia”, one of Sonic Youth’s best-known songs, was partly inspired by Keller. In an e-mail, Gordon said that her breakup with Moore was ‘a weird kind of death but in a strange way it reminds me of my brother… . This person who you lived with for so long is suddenly someone else.’
- The New Yorker

songs.title: Incinerate

description.plain:
This song was released in 2006 as the leading single off SY’s “Rather Ripped” album.

Moore sings the song, taking a rather conventional trope – the idea of being incinerated as a metaphor for feeling deep, maddening passion and desire – but taking it to rather extreme levels.

The music video for the song was directed by French arthouse film-maker Claire Denis and features unusually framed close-ups of the band playing live, mostly illuminated by warm, red lights, of a fiery tone.

description.plain:
In her autobiography Girl in a Band, Kim says the song is about Joe Cole. A friend of theirs who was murdered during a robbery in Venice, Los Angeles in front of his friend and roomate Henry Rollins.



She says:

When Henry called to tell me about Joe. I burst into tears. I didn’t get over it for a couple of years, to be honest. The senseless, random act of violence against someone so full of life and innocence, was mind-blowing, and I hated Los Angeles for a long time after that. I wrote the song “JC” about Joe, while Thurston wrote “100%”. It was hard to sing without tearing up.

songs.full_title: The Diamond Sea by Sonic Youth
songs.title: The Diamond Sea

description.plain:
A 20 minute exploration of pop and noise, which was actually released as a single with an accompanying music video, “The Diamond Sea”, is the longest track on the Sonic Youth catalogue – excluding the SYR releases, of course. It encapsulates very well what the band was about. As Eric Wagoner wrote for Magnet Magazine:

“The Diamond Sea” is many things at once: a catchy, evocative pop number, wistful and meditative; a long noise workout; an atmospheric jam; a showcase for each band member in turn; an aural history of the group’s development from skronky art rock to woozy romantics; and a statement of purpose for a band that wanted to be all of that, and also remain independent, and also reach the widest audience possible. In short—or at length—it’s a great shambling mess of a song by a great shambling group, and a reminder of the sort of serious musicianship at the heart that band’s longevity. Block out time for the full version; as a summation of Sonic Youth’s blend of styles and approaches into a sui generis aesthetic, it’s better than any compilation.

Three different versions of the song were officially released: in the album Washing Machine there is a 19-minute cut; in The Diamond Sea single, there is a five-minute radio edit and a 25-minute alternate ending version, which was later also released in the compilation The Destoyed Room; finally, there’s a shorter, four-minute edit in the Little Trouble Girl single.

songs.title: The Sprawl

description.plain:
At the time of release, this was the longest song to have appeared on a full-length Sonic Youth record (not counting “The Good and the Bad” on the band’s eponymous debut EP).

Kim claims to have gotten the title off of a William Gibson novel entitled Mona Lisa Overdrive.



A portion of the lyrics are based on another book, The Stars at Noon by Denis Johnson.



Some lines were bits and pieces of dialogue overheard from prostitutes, junkies and denizens on the streets of New York.

songs.full_title: Youth Against Fascism (Hate Song) by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Youth Against Fascism (Hate Song)

description.plain:
“Youth Against Fascism” is a straightforward punk anthem written by Thurston Moore and much less subtle than most of SY’s politically-oriented songs.

The song is an attack on various forms of fascism (or crypto-fascism) that were happening in America at that time, from president Bush’s warmongering, to the KKK, from Nazi skinhead punk bands to a Supreme Court case involving sexism and racism.

The youth (meaning of course both Sonic Youth and young people in general) will not stand still and watch all this happen. This is a basically an Antifa call to arms.

songs.title: Sunday

description.plain:
The only single from the album A Thousand Leaves, it had actually been previously released in the Soundtrack of the 1996 Richard Linklater movie SubUrbia, although using a different, much longer take, clocking at around 8 minutes. The LP version is 5 minutes long, and the radio edit is around 3 minutes, cutting almost all of the guitar work in the middle of the song.



The video for “Sunday” became iconic. It was directed by indie filmmaker Harmoy Korine and featured Macaulay Culkin – who, at the time, had been basically hiding from media attention for the last 5 years – and his then-fiancé Rachel Miner.

The main riff in the song was essentially stolen from the band Helium and their song “Skeleton” – one of Thurston’s favourite bands. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VK2q71f0XOI

songs.title: Silver Rocket

description.plain:
This is the second track off Sonic Youth’s critically acclaimed fifth studio album “Daydream Nation”. It was ranked No. 79 in the Rolling Stone magazine’s list of the “100 Greatest Guitar Songs of All Time”

It was also released twice as a single, both very rare. One 7'‘ vinyl was released by Canadian label Forced Exposure and features a live version of the song, with some other live experimentalisms for B-Sides. A Spanish label also released a different live version of the song as a split 7’‘ b/w a couple of live pieces by the Miracle Workers.

songs.full_title: Little Trouble Girl by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Little Trouble Girl

description.plain:
“Little Trouble Girl” is the second single released off 1995’s Washing Machine. It features vocals by Kim Gordon, Kim Deal (from the Pixies and The Breeders) along with Memphis singer-songwriters Melissa Dunn and Lorette Velvette.

Described in Rolling Stone magazine as a “dramatic, earnest coming-of-age story”, and in Entertainment Weekly as a “a teen-pregnancy lullaby”, in her book Girl in A Band, Gordon explained the lyrics as being about

wanting to be seen for who you really are, being able to express those parts of yourself that aren’t “good girl” but that are just as real and true.

songs.title: Sugar Kane

description.plain:
Sugar Kane Kowalczyk is the name of Marilyn Monroe’s character in 1959’s “Some Like it Hot”, one of her most recognizable roles,  According to the Hits are for Squares liner notes,

The song is inspired by the notion of emotional contact we feel for celebrities on the edge and our desire ro “save” them.

The title may also be a reference to the Jeff Beck Group’s 1972 song “Sugar Cane”.

The song was released as the third single off Dirty. A music video directed by Nick Egan was made. In it, the band performs in a NYC fashion show showcasing a “Grunge Collection” of clothing designed by Kim Gordon’s friend Marc Jacobs for Perry Ellis in 1992.
The video also features the first ever film appearance of actress Chloë Sevigny, two years before her breakthrough on Larry Clark’s Kids. She seemingly plays the title character in the song.
According to sonicyouth.com the band wanted Drew Barrymore in the video too.

songs.full_title: My Friend Goo by Sonic Youth
songs.title: My Friend Goo

description.plain:
Kim Gordon wrote the lyrics to this song and sang it together with Thurston Moore. It eventually served as quasi-title track to their first major label release, Goo, after the working title, “Blowjob?” was discarded,

Seems like a fitting choice, since the song’s lyrics are an ironical take on late 80s-early 90s alternative kids, their slacker attitude and concern with coolness.

Goo, like Scooter and Jinx, are all characters in Raymond Pettibon’s 1989 movie “Sir Drone”. Pettibon also did the cover for the record.

songs.title: Trilogy

description.plain:
The closing song to the classic Daydream Nation is a three-part piece. Some CD versions slice it into different tracks, but the liner notes separate it as:
a) “The Wonder”
b) “Hyperstation”
z) “Eliminator Jr.”

While parts a) and b) fit more seamlessly, and are both sung by Thurston Moore, part z) breaks the rhythm with much heavier and faster riffs, and is sung by Kim Gordon.

songs.title: ’Cross the Breeze

description.plain:
The fourth track on Daydream Nation is one the longest, featuring an extended intro and outro of aggressive guitar dissonance.

There are a lot of theories about the meaning of the song. Some say that the song is about pedophilia and religion, others say that the song is about politic figures and poor people.

The band has never stated what’s the real meaning of the song, so it’s open to interpretation.

songs.full_title: Kill Yr Idols by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Kill Yr Idols

description.plain:
“Kill Yr Idols” was Sonic Youth’s reaction to the rather cold appraisal famed rock critic Robert Christgau (of The Village Voice) gave to their first two albums. Christgau, in fact, didn’t even seem to be convinced that the band was actually playing rock music.

From the review for Sonic Youth:

The best [songs] never last long enough. Not for nothing is the sonic grown-up so attached to phony grandeur. [Letter grade:] C

So, understandably, the band wasn’t amused.

Christgau replied to this song in his review of Kill Yr Idols:

Idolization is for rock stars, even rock stars manqué like these impotent bohos–critics just want a little respect. So if it’s not too hypersensitive of me, I wasn’t flattered to hear my name pronounced right, not on this particular title track…

Sonic Youth replied by renaming the song to “I Killed Christgau with My Big Fuckin' Dick” on the (Over)Kill Yr Idols EP. Released through the music magazine Forced Exposure, the title was actually suggested by fellow critic Byron Coley.

songs.title: Hey Joni

description.plain:
The title is said to be a reference to both the song “Hey Joe” and the artist Joni Mitchell.

This song also alludes to the works of William Gibson’s Neuromancer with the line “In this broken town, can you still jack in/And know what to do?” These feature similarly on Ranaldo’s two other songs on the album, the rarely played “Rain King” — a homage to Pere Ubu and perhaps Saul Bellow’s Henderson the Rain King — and “Eric’s Trip”.

songs.title: Disappearer

description.plain:
According to the Hits are for Squares liner notes,

“Disappearer” was the second single off Goo and was a lyrical take on how signs – be they commercially manufactured or naturally occurring phenomena – affect one’s psychological perspective. The video, directed by Todd Haynes, whom the band sought after viewing his incredible yet banned film “Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story”, was shot amongst the glaring neon signs of downtown Toronto.

songs.full_title: Death Valley '69 by Sonic Youth (Ft. Lydia Lunch)
songs.title: Death Valley ’69

description.plain:
“Death Valley ‘69” is the eight track on Sonic Youth’s 1985 album Bad Moon Rising, following “Justice is Might”. It was the main single released from the album. The song prominently features popular No Wave artist Lydia Lunch, who wrote the song’s verses.



The video was shot partly in a Long Island nature reserve (where Lee Ranaldo used to get high with his friends as a teen) and partly in director Richard Kern’s apartment on the same day that Ranaldo’s son Cody was born. From Goodbye 20th Century:

…throughout the day, Ranaldo was continually being handed a phone and told that his wife Amanda was about to give birth – and also being told by Kern he couldn’t leave yet. Finally, when filming was done, Ranaldo ran home, cleaned the fake gore from his chest, and dashed to the hospital; his son arrived several hours later.)

The video (along with the song) is a play on the Manson Family murders. Additional footage was taken from the 1970 cult-classic hippie movie The Strawberry Statement, and film of the actress Elizabeth “Lung Leg” Carr, who appeared on the cover of EVOL.

songs.full_title: I Dreamed I Dream by Sonic Youth
songs.title: I Dreamed I Dream

description.plain:
“I Dreamed I Dream” was originally an instrumental titled “Where the Red Fern Grows” (after the classic children’s novel).



Inspired by the vocal experiments of artists like The B-52’s and Laurie Anderson, the band devised an overlapping dual vocal part for Lee Ranaldo and Kim Gordon. Ranaldo’s part, like most of the band’s early lyrics, was taken from his journal of poetry – however, at the time of recording, Gordon’s part hadn’t been finished. So, taking a cue from a song she’d written for her previous band (“Cosmopolitan Girl” by CKM), the group flipped through magazines and picked out interesting-sounding sentences for her to sing.

songs.title: Wish Fulfillment

description.plain:
The only song written and sung by experimentalist Lee Ranaldo left on one of SY’s most pop albums, as the exquisite “Genetic” was demoted to b-side.

In a recent interview with a Brazilian website, Ranaldo has been revealing, tho still partly mysterious about the meaning of the lyrics and about his dissatisfaction with the way the track ultimately was recorded.

[The inspiration behind this song] is a bit personal. […] It is related to some stuff inside the band. There’s a deluxe version of Dirty that has a demo version of it. It is a much more beautiful, silent song than the way we did it in the album. Because sometimes Sonic Youth had problems wrapping their heads around music I brought in […] The “Wish Fulfillment” in the album was never my vision of the way it is supposed to sound. It ended up being much more violent than I thought it would be.
[…] It is about people who played in bands just to get famous and appear on magazine covers. All of that versus those who were doing it for the art, without thinking what the audience would think. […] the song is about some specific people.

songs.full_title: Madonna, Sean and Me by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Madonna, Sean and Me

description.plain:
The ninth track on the 1986 Sonic Youth album, Evol, following “Marilyn Moore”.

The original EVOL LP had a locked groove at the end of “Expressway”, so the song played infinitely (on the label of the LP, the track’s time is indicated w/ an infinity symbol).
[The song is] titled ‘Madonna, Sean and Me’ on the back cover of EVOL and titled ‘The Crucifixion of Sean Penn’ on the lyric sheet on the record sleeve/CD liners.

— Official Sonic Youth Archive



An early demo version of the song was also released in a bootleg single in February, 1988. It was titled “Stick Me Donna Magick Momma” and was b/w a live version of “Making the Nature Scene” from a 1983 concert in Berlin.

songs.title: Tom Violence

description.plain:
The first track on Sonic Youth’s 1986 album, Evol.



It is about Television’s frontman Tom Verlaine – notice the song titles, the singer’s name and the bands acronyms would all be “T.V.”. It is also a nod to the American hardcore scene of the early 1980s.

The working title was “Dear Life”, and it was listed as “Tom Valence” in the Hold That Tiger live album.

songs.title: JC

description.plain:
In her autobiography “Girl in a band”, Kim says the song is about Joe Cole. A friend of theirs who was murdered during a robbery in Venice, Los Angeles in front of his friend and roomate Henry Rollins.



She says:

When Henry called to tell me about Joe. I burst into tears. I didn’t get over it for a couple of years, to be honest. The senseless, random act of violence against someone so full of life and innocence, was mind-blowing, and I hated Los Angeles for a long time after that. I wrote the song “JC” about Joe, while Thurston wrote “100%”. It was hard to sing without tearing up.

songs.title: Hallowe’en

description.plain:
The eleventh and final track on Sonic Youth’s 1986 CD release of the album, Bad Moon Rising, following “Flower”. Both were the only songs in the record not recorded at the BC Studios.

It was first released as a 12'‘ single together with “Flower”.

In her memoir, “Girl in a Band”, Kim Gordon says that the lyrics were inspired by watching Henry Rollins at a Black Flag’s house party gig.

songs.title: Chapel Hill

description.plain:
The owner of Internationalist Books in Chapel Hill, Bob Sheldon, was considered by many the cornerstone Chapel Hill’s progressive and radical scene. In 1991, someone walked into his bookstore and shot him; the murder remains unsolved. Many suspect that it was executed by the CIA.

Although Chapel Hill does have a productive scene, many argue that it is dead by comparison to its late 80s incarnation. The Cat’s Cradle itself has moved since this song’s release.  The original Intl. Bookstore was right around the corner from the original Cat’s Cradle location.

It was one of the first songs written for Dirty, premiered on the August ‘91 Euro-tour (when The Year Punk Broke was filmed).

songs.title: Becuz

description.plain:
This song bears a conscious resemblance to Patti Smith’s Because The Night. The working title was “Jim Carroll”, an homage to yet another American punk poet.

It was split in two parts, the instrumental coda going to track 9 in the album (untitled in the album liner notes). The idea was to make it more accessible as an album opener.

songs.title: Cotton Crown

description.plain:
“Cotton Crown” is the ninth track on Sonic Youth fourth studio album, Sister, and was also released as an “official bootleg” 7'‘ record, b/w “PCH”.
It was the the first song in which Kim and Thurston sing together—although in most live versions, Thurston used to sing it alone.



The song is sometimes styled as “Kotton Krown” in the album’s first edition booklet, for instance.

songs.title: Reena

description.plain:
According to sonicyouth.com, Kim Gordon has said about this song:

I was sort of inspired by this book, Reena Spauling, who is kind of a fictional character. It’s a collaborative piece of writing by a bunch of people. It’s a fictional character about this fantastic kind of girl creature who makes her way in the art world, art fashion world, in New York. And she kind of reminds me of people that you meet who seem fascinating, but they’re crazy. And you don’t know why they’re fascinating, and it just could be in simple things they do or some mystery. It’s kind of like one of those gross friendship crush songs, because I just thought I had never written a song about that. And it’s also–the name of this became the name of this gallery where I’ve shown. So, I kind of wanted to continue the myth of Reena Spauling.

Here is the website for the Reena Spaulding Fine Arts project. And here’s a picture taken in their gallery:



And a piece of art by Kim Gordon for the project:

songs.full_title: In the Kingdom #19 by Sonic Youth
songs.title: In the Kingdom #19

description.plain:
The fourth track on Sonic Youth’s 1986 album Evol.

Mike Watt’s contribution to this track was the first bass recording he’d done since the death of his best friend and fellow Minutemen member D. Boon in a 1985 van crash. In addition to the nature of the poem/song itself, the recording features a number of traffic samples.
According to Confusion is Next, Thurston threw some lit firecrackers into the booth while Lee was laying down his vocal track, much to Lee’s horror. The exploding firecrackers could be audible around 0:56.
There’s also some chatter at the end of the song, including some insightful wordplay courtesy of Thurston, and Mike Watt quoting the Minutemen tune ‘What Is It?’.

— Official Sonic Youth Archive

songs.title: Junkie’s Promise

description.plain:
“Junkie’s Promise”, was described as a “heroin vignette”.

Like tons of rock songs released in the second half of the 1990s, it was interpreted as being about Kurt Cobain. However, in the 2008 book Psychic Confusion: The Sonic Youth Story, Moore clarified that the song:

is purely about the emotional relationship between friends, one of which is a user. Any individual involved with drug addiction will lie to his friends for the self-serving need. It’s the cruelest truth of the situation. Kurt may fit this profile and he was surely in my mind as I wrote but the song is not a specific dedication to him.

songs.title: Purr

description.plain:
Sonic Youth first performed Dirty material on the same August 1991 tour that would result in “1991: The Year Punk Broke”, playing “Orange Rolls, Angel’s Spit” and “Chapel Hill” nightly. In late October they did one last show of the year (except for the infamous acoustic “Bridge Benefit” appearance), debuting “Purr” and “Sugar Kane”.

Prior to the album’s release in July 1992, Sonic Youth did a brief northeast tour, finishing with a free show in Central Park on July 4th.

Also in July was a Mark Goodier session where SY recorded new versions of 3 songs from Dirty, along with a furious rendition of “Burning Spear”.

 In addition to a fairly straightforward version of “Youth Against Fascism”, they recorded “Creme Brulee” (the only “live” performance, a great contrast to the LP version) and “Purr”, with Thurston playing acoustic guitar – this one ended up on the Youth Against Fascism and Sugar Kane singles as well.

songs.title: Secret Girl

description.plain:
The seventh track on the 1986 Sonic Youth album, Evol, following the instrumental “Death to our Friends”. The song begins with guitar noise but then cuts to a piano playing with Kim Gordon’s spoken word piece at 1:13. The working title was “Piano Tape”. The song is listed as “Secret Girls” on the inner label of the LP release.

Thurston [Moore] recorded the piano onto cassette, and then slowed it down for the song’s backdrop.
‘I’m The Boy That Can Enjoy Invisibility – J.J.’ is etched into the runout groove of the Flower/Halloween 12". J.J. is James Joyce, whom the quote is taken from.

— Official Sonic Youth Archive

Variations of this songs' theme were used in the Made in USA soundtrack, recorded by the band.

songs.full_title: The World Looks Red by Sonic Youth
songs.title: The World Looks Red

description.plain:
“The World Looks Red” is the sixth song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

The lyrics to “World” were written by Michael Gira, leader of the noise rock band Swans. Sonic Youth and Swans both played the same circles in the New York no wave scene and shared the same rehearsal space (a dilapidated former Pentacostal church) in the early 1980s. The two bands formed a close friendship. Sonic Youth’s first tour, a 1982 circuit of the American South, was in support of Swans. Gira wrote the lyrics intending to convey “a general sense of paranoia”.

This is the first song in which Moore used a guitar tempered with a broken drumstick shoved through the strings, a favorite technique of the band’s.

33 years after this song was recorded, Gira reused the lyrics for “The World Looks Red/The World Looks Black” off of Swans' 2016 effort, The Glowing Man.

songs.title: Skip Tracer

description.plain:
Written and sung by Lee Ranaldo, making it his second contribution for Washing Machine after shying away completely from vocal duties on Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star. It’s also the first time since Sonic Youth’s magnum opus Daydream Nation that Ranaldo sings more than a single song on a record.

The song was written about a concert by Candian band Mecca Normal that Lee attended to. Leah Singer also helped with the lyrics. The working title for the song was “Pick Droppa”.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
This she did in public for us to see

Between the trains and cars
Broken glass and lost hub-caps, images of a gun
Row house, row house pass through
Let the city rise up to fill the screen
Clothes flung out of closets, doorknobs falling off
The guitar guy played real good feedback, and super sounding riffs
With his mild mannered look on, yeah he was truly hip
The girl started out in red patent leather
Very "I'm in a band" with knee pads

Shouting the poetic truths of high school journal keepers

[Verse 2]

Now we tone-soul merge ideas, of song forms and freedom

Yes sir, yes sir, step right up

None of us know, where we're trying to get to

What we're we trying to build
Now we tone-soul merge ideas, of song forms and freedom
Seasons out of life, nothing is out of reach
L.A. is more confusing now, than anywhere I've ever been to
I'm from New York City, breath it out and let it in
[Break]
Where are you now
When your broken eyes are closed?
Head in a cloudy dream, green and sailboats
Borrowed and never returned
Emotions, books, outlooks on life

Hello 2015!
Hello 2015!1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Society Is a Hole by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Society Is a Hole

description.plain:
The second track on Sonic Youth’s 1985 album, Bad Moon Rising.



The track begins with a sample from Lou Reed’s Metal Machine Music. For the last 50 seconds of the song, Not Right by The Stooges, although distorted, can roughly be heard playing through an amplifier. The band would often play tapes like this through their amps during concerts as a sort of interstitial music while the band members switched guitars.



Sonic Youth also covered I Wanna Be Your Dog by The Stooges on their 1983 album Confusion Is Sex.

songs.title: Scooter + Jinx

description.plain:
Thurston explains the track’s origins in Guitar Player, August 1991:

For “Scooter and Jinx” I 10'ed everything on my amp. There’s no guitar, just amp sound, and at the end you can hear a pop where the amp blows up. We just ran it to tape, 24 tracks.

According to the band’s biography  written by David Browne, they were recording “Mildred Pierce” when this happened.

The experimental studio piece was oftenplayed through an amplifier before encores in 1990.

The video for the song is set to a 1990 Richard Kern film entitled “Money Love”.

Like Goo, Scooter and Jinx are characters in Raymond Pettibon’s 1989 movie “Sir Drone”. Pettibon also did the cover for the record.

songs.full_title: Protect Me You by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Protect Me You

description.plain:
“Protect Me You” is the second song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

Kim Gordon wrote the song, inspired in part by Lydia Lunch’s air of “ravaged innocence”. She was quite reluctant to sing the song, being very self-conscious of her voice. In order to ease some of the pressure, Lee Ranaldo opted to play the bass part for her—as a result, this is the only song in the Sonic Youth catalog on which Lee plays bass. It was rarely played live.

In a 1983 article for Artforum magazine, rock critic Greil Marcus described this song (as well as “Confusion is Next”) as:

…[something] that resembled nothing so much as the sort of chants little kids come up with when they’ve been sent to their rooms without supper.

songs.full_title: Confusion Is Next by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Confusion Is Next

description.plain:
“Confusion is Next” is the seventh song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

“Confusion” was the first song the band recorded for the Confusion is Sex sessions. It was inspired in equal parts by Lydia Lunch (who later worked with the band on the Bad Moon Rising album), hardcore punk, and Henry Miller’s novel Tropic of Capricorn.



The original plan was to record “Confusion is Next” as a 7" single in Manhattan’s Fun City studios. Glenn Branca, Lee Ranaldo’s mentor and the head of the band’s label, Neutral Records, responded positively to the initial sessions and encouraged the band to record all their new material for a full studio album (which became Confusion is Sex).

songs.full_title: Self Obsessed and Sexxee by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Self Obsessed and Sexxee

description.plain:
This song is a tribute to alternative rock’s new breed. Thurston Moore explained the song with this words:

It’s not about Courtney Love, it’s not about Kathleen Hanna from Bikini Kill. It’s just sort of about being attracted to somebody who’s obviously out of control with self-obsession in the high-profile alternative-rock world.

Although the song sounds a tad critical, Hanna was friends with Sonic Youth and even participated in the music video for their song “Bull in the Heather” off the same album.

songs.title: Screaming Skull

description.plain:
This song’s lyrics were written  after a conversation with Dave Markey about the SST Superstore, an independent record store in Los Angeles. Markey is a movie director famous for 1991: The Year Punk Broke and many music videos for underground bands (including Sonic Youth and Black Flag).

By the time Experimental Jet Set… came out, it was already their third album on a major label, and here they seem to be longing for their time as underground artists, releasing albums through SST records.

Throughout the song, the band name-drops a few of the bands, persons and records that made their underground music “society” of the 1980s great.

songs.full_title: (She's In A) Bad Mood by Sonic Youth
songs.title: (She’s In A) Bad Mood

description.plain:
“(She’s In A) Bad Mood” is the opening song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex. On its original vinyl release, if you listen closely, you can hear engineer John Erskine yelling for the band to start playing at the beginning. Erskine, in the makeshift Fun City studio, couldn’t actually see the band when they recorded, so he’d have to yell to let them know when he began rolling tape.

The song was written by Thurston Moore for frequent collaborator Lydia Lunch, who, according to him, “made bad mood an art form.”

songs.title: Shaking Hell

description.plain:
“Shaking Hell” is the fourth song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

The song was written on commission for conceptual artist (and close friend of Kim Gordon) Dan Graham. Graham was splicing together a documentary titled Rock My Religion, which posited a deep similarity between rock concerts of the time and fervent religious gatherings like those of snake-handler Baptists or the early Puritans. He’d asked Gordon to contribute a song to its soundtrack. Inspired by Graham’s theory and her deep-seated distrust of advertisers and the fashion industry, she wrote “Shaking Hell” in response.

While recording, Gordon accidentally lost her preferred vocal take, and had to dub it over with a tape of a live performance.

In the January 1983 issue of Artforum, famed rock critic Greil Marcus described the song as:

…[an ambush, a door slammed in your face] as you drifted in the other music. “Shaking Hell” – Gordon seemingly singing to the mirror – starts out as another mood piece. It chases its title, catches it, and then slowly, deliberately erases the lines between submission and domination, fantasy and rape, performance and violence, crimes and punishment.

songs.full_title: Freezer Burn  / I Wanna Be Your Dog by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Freezer Burn  / I Wanna Be Your Dog
songs.title_with_featured: Freezer Burn  / I Wanna Be Your Dog

description.plain:
“Freezer Burn/I Wanna Be Your Dog” is the third song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

“Freezer Burn” was recorded in the walk-in freezer of a deli near the band’s recording studio. The band often used it as one of their interstitial tapes which they’d play through their amplifiers while the band switched guitars (alongside songs like Madonna’s “Into the Groove”).

“I Wanna Be Yr Dog” is a cover of the Stooges song, recorded live at the Pier in Raleigh, North Carolina, Nov. 15, 1982. The album version cuts in on the line “Now I’m ready to feel your hand” and progresses from there.

Here’s how rock critic Greil Marcus described his impressions of Kim Gordon singing “Dog” in the January 1983 issue of Artforum magazine.

That’s where Gordon’s howling dive into “I Wanna Be Your Dog” begins – in your awe at her own submission to the music, unless it’s Gordon’s awe at her own submission, or her awe-struck anticipation of yours. The performance is absolutely unstable, three minutes of panic, and it still bubbles like a witches' cauldron; it’ll dissolve anything. This was a kind of fire nobody was playing with in 1982 and 1983 – not that I heard, anyway.

In 1987, Iggy Pop joined the band onstage in London to sing “I Wanna Be Your Dog”. Footage of this performance was released on the 1995 videotape Screaming Fields of Sonic Love.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iN1pAiyDcIs

Other musicians who’ve joined the band for “Dog” include Mark Arm and Steve Turner of Mudhoney, Nick Cave and original Stooges guitarist Ron Asheton.

songs.title: Inhuman

description.plain:
“Inhuman” is the fifth song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

Thurston Moore plays bass and sings on this song, while guitarist Lee Ranaldo plays a modified zither. This zither now resides in the permanent collection of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland.



(pictured: Lee and Thurston during a performance of “Inhuman”, from the Sonic Death booklet.)

To achieve a properly fucked-up vocal sound, Moore fed his microphone into a blown-out amplifier. In addition, Jim Sclavunos recorded his snare drum part in the studio bathroom to get the right tone.

songs.full_title: The Burning Spear by Sonic Youth
songs.title: The Burning Spear

description.plain:
“The Burning Spear”, written by Thurston Moore, was titled in tribute to the famed roots reggae musician Burning Spear. Thurston was a fan of Jamaican reggae, often frequenting a local record shop that specialized in it. In fact, he helped Kim Gordon learn to play bass by having her improvise to a Black Uhuru record. This song was Thurston’s attempt to imbue the band’s no wave sound with a bit of reggae—specifically in the “really spooked-out” bass line.

Lee Ranaldo’s addition to the song, however, took the sound firmly in the other direction: he played an electric drill with a contact mic plugged into a wah-wah pedal. During recording, the engineer reportedly voiced concerns that the sound of the drill was throwing off all the other instruments on the console. The band shrugged it off because they liked it that way.

Moore intended for “The Burning Spear” to be a sort of “primitivist announcement to the world”, a mission statement for the group’s new chaotic noise rock sound. Their website describes it as “essentially the band’s first song.”

songs.title: Pattern Recognition

description.plain:
Sonic Youth’s composition process, at least during the 2000s, involved the band first collectively writing the music and then deciding who was going to sing in it. Usually the singer also wrote the lyrics, but not always. Most songs usually had a working title which generally changed once lyrics were added.

According to sonicyouth.com, for this one, Thurston was the original vocalist, and they called it “It’s the Mayhem!” – the words he sang were Kim now sings “You’re the one!”. Partially because people thought it sounded like “Instant Mayhem” (Don Fleming’s label), they changed the lyrics and Kim ended up delivering her own interpretation of the song.

She based her version in a then-recent William Gibson novel “Pattern Recognition”



She has already wrote a song based on a Gibson novel, The Sprawl.

songs.title: The Empty Page

description.plain:
The fifth of five new compositions debuted by Sonic Youth in 2001. However, Thurston has been performing the song acoustically in various live solo sets since at least 1999.

This song unsurprisingly became the lead-off track for Murray Street. A video was created using digicam tour footage, available on the Corporate Ghost DVD.

Sonic Youth performed this track on the Carson Daly show.

songs.full_title: Making the Nature Scene by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Making the Nature Scene

description.plain:
“Making the Nature Scene” is the penultimate song on Sonic Youth’s first full-length album, Confusion is Sex.

It’s the only song on Confusion that features original drummer Bob Bert (other than the live version of “I Wanna Be Your Dog”). At the time of recording, the band’s drummer Jim Sclavunos, who’d previously worked with Thurston Moore in Lydia Lunch’s backing band. Sclavunos was skilled, but the band was rather unhappy with his performance on this song. Written with Bert behind the kit, he’d performed the song with a certain wanton savagery that Sclavunos just couldn’t replicate. The band briefly joked about re-hiring Bert so he could do it the way they were used to. Sclavunos, under a great deal of stress due to his relationship with Ranaldo’s ex (who did not appreciate the time he spent with the band) and a worsening problem with speed and acid, overheard the joke and abruptly quit. Thus, the band were forced to live up to their joke and re-hire Bert.

Bert was certainly surprised by their sudden job offer, but he’d been practicing in the meantime and was well-prepared. They initially hired him for the one session only—Bert proceeded to play so heavily and whole-heartedly that his drum heads had to be replaced. They then let him join the band for a couple shows until they’d found a replacement. Then, a couple of shows turned into a European tour and Bert was back.

Kim Gordon wrote the song about the prostitutes that convened around her apartment and worked the streets in her neighborhood. Gordon also collaborated with video artist Tony Oursler (who also lent a still from one of his films to the cover of EVOL) on a video project entitled “Making the Nature Scene”, about the architecture of Manhattan rock clubs.

songs.full_title: Female Mechanic Now on Duty by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Female Mechanic Now on Duty

description.plain:
One of the many tracks in A Thousand Leaves—probably SY’s most feminist album—to deal with gender issues.

Kim Gordon wrote it about male music journalists' reactions to female musicians. The mid-to-late-1990s saw a rise in popularity of female singer-songwriters marketed as being independent and strong in character, but also often criticized for being just following a profitable trend of the time. Alanis Morissette, Sheryl Crow and Jewel were some of them, but Gordon had in mind Meredith Brooks and her hit “Bitch” when she wrote “Female Mechanic…”.

Being a mechanic, of course, is a role not stereotypically seen as feminine. The lyrics are about what was expected and demanded of women at the end of the 20th Century (and still is).



The working title was “Static Overview”.

songs.title: Dude Ranch Nurse

description.plain:
The title of this song was lifted from the 14th book in the Cherry Ames series of mystery novels.
As with the all volumes from 7 to 17 in the series, it was written by Us writer Julie Campbell Tathan, and it centers in a mystery-solving nurse.



Kim Gordon has introduced this song as an “anti-Bush song”

songs.full_title: Hits of Sunshine (For Allen Ginsberg) by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Hits of Sunshine (For Allen Ginsberg)

description.plain: Allen Ginsberg was an American poet, philosopher and writer. He is considered to be one of the leading figures of both the Beat Generation during the 1950s and the counterculture that soon followed. He vigorously opposed militarism, economic materialism and sexual repression and was known as embodying various aspects of this counterculture, such as his views on drugs, hostility to bureaucracy and openness to Eastern religions.

songs.full_title: Bubblegum by Sonic Youth (Ft. Mike Watt)
songs.title: Bubblegum

description.plain:
The final track on the 1986 Sonic Youth album, Evol’s CD release. Previously released as a B-side to the single “Starpower”.

A cover of Kim Fowley’s original. The song is sung by Kim Gordon, Lee Ranaldo and Thurston Moore together. Mike Watt, from Minutemen plays bass.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TBvr_9I143U
Instead of learning the song as a band, they recorded the original version of the song to tape and everybody overdubbed their parts, then they erased the original.

songs.full_title: Satan Is Boring by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Satan Is Boring

description.plain:
According to Sonic Youth biographer David Browne, “Satan is Boring” was inspired by the “Say You Love Satan Killer” Ricky Kasso, who stabbed his 17-year-old friend Gary Lauwers to death in the Aztakea Woods of Northport, Long Island while the two were tripping on LSD with two other metalhead friends.



While stabbing Lauwers 17-36 times and slicing out his eyeballs, Kasso reportedly commanded his victim to “Say you love Satan,” to which Lawers replied, “I love my mother.”

The widely publicized incident helped fuel the hysteria over Satanism that was prevalent in the 1980’s and 90’s.

songs.title: Sleepin’ Around

description.plain: “Sleepin' Around”, the fourth song on Rather Ripped, is a song sung by Thurston Moore, seemingly taking a negative view of infidelity. This song would later become quite ironic, considering Moore’s infidelity caused his breakup with Kim Gordon, which, in turn, caused Sonic Youth to break up.

songs.title: New Hampshire

description.plain:
The song describes ‘Martin Scorsese Presents Salute to the Blues’ Concert February 6, 2003 at Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

“New Hampshire” is a song I brought in, written about… sort of a sentimental thing after reading the oral history of Aerosmith. I grew up in the early ‘70s in New England, and this book was the first one I’d read to really capture what life was like up there during that time. Being in bands and trying to do something and driving down to New York… that kind of lifestyle. At the same time, I’d gone to see this blues event at Madison Square Garden that Martin Scorsese did. [Aerosmith members] Steven [Tyler] and Joe [Perry] came out. It was a really genuine thing for these guys. After all the bullshit of fame, drugs and all this stuff, it came down to them being so happy to be in the same place as B.B. King. That really struck me. The song was basically noting certain things happening at this show.


Thurston Moore – Nude as the News interview

description.plain:
“Kim Gordon and the Arthur Doyle Hand Cream” is the fourth track off of Sonic Nurse. The name of the track was changed from the original “Mariah Carey And The Arthur Doyle Hand Cream,” due to controversy surrounding the use of Mariah Carey’s name in the title.

The song was debuted live in Japan in 2003, over a year before the release of the album.

songs.full_title: Rain on Tin by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Rain on Tin

description.plain:
According to the Hits are for Squares liner notes,

“Rain on Tin” was written as a prayer and cry for love and unity after the destruction of September 11, 2001, in New York City that was shared by gentle folk the world over.

The working title was “Celtic Frost” and one of the riffs in the song was contained in a solo acoustic piece by Thurston Moore, “Altar Boy, Church Basement”, recorded on 9/16/99 and released on the Hurricane Floyd CD.

songs.title: Brother James

description.plain:
“Brother James” was primarily inspired by the book Mystery Train: Images of America in Popular Music, a study of six popular musicians by rock critic Greil Marcus. A favorite of the band’s, it remained a staple of their setlists for 25 years.

The song was prominently featured in Dan Graham’s 1984 documentary Rock My Religion, where it’s played over footage of serpent-handling Pentecostals.

annotatable.link_title: NYC Ghosts & Flowers by Sonic Youth
annotatable.title: NYC Ghosts & Flowers

body.plain: Title track for the 2000 album, with free-form, beatnik-inspired poetry lyrics by lee Ranaldo, very similar to his published books.

songs.lyrics:
When the phone rang, 3 in the morning
Dead middle of night
There was nothing on the line
I set back the silent receiver
Tiny flames lit in my head
Hey did any of you freaks here ever remember Lenny?
I can't remember his last name

He's turned to dust now, one of the chosen few
Left out in the rain, out of town again
Left out in the rain, ocean bound I guess

Between the mattress and a column of hazy faces
I remember every word you said
Quite a clear picture
Every word you said

The door was open but the way was not lit
And there was no way out of my head

On a crimson highway by a chrome bumper I last saw you
Alive

Inclined to thrive
Evening fireflies lit sparks around your head
But wait a minute let's back up a bit
Some famous stars were busted down on fashion avenue
Impersonating real men
Not knowing who they really were
Now here at dark corners all is calm and quiet
And good
The kids are up late dreaming quiet questions
In a graceful mood

Can you please pass me a jug of winter light?
Fold me in an ocean's whim?
In sweet corrosive fire light?
In the city made of tin?
Are you famous under the skin?
Familiar with the things you wanted?
Able now to take it all in?
Making peace with every hole in the story?

Did lightning keep you up all night?
Illuminate the soot and grit?
Can you tell how high the sky tonight?
Dig out from under in spite of it?
Can you cover up the one that floats?
Can you push back the hours?

I hear your voice
I speak your name
Among New York City ghosts and flowers

Will we meet?
To run again?
Through New York City ghosts and flowersEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Quest for the Cup by Sonic Youth
songs.title: Quest for the Cup

description.plain:
Written as a fantasy response to the Drew Barrymore Guess jeans advertisements in 1993, hence the capitalization of the word “GUESS” in the lyrics in the liner notes.



During recording, Butch Vig commented that Kim’s guitar intro was too similar to Led Zeppelin’s “Whole Lotta Love”. Kim claimed it was intentional, according to Confusion is Next.
